did.langmaterial: The material is in English Boxes 6-8 also contain Japanese language material.
did.abstract: The Turner Geriatric Clinic was established in 1978 as an extension of the University of Michigan Hospital and is devoted to the medical and social care of the elderly. The collection ranges from 1979 to 2009 (bulk 1990-2008) and contains material on community and social work programs, including photographs, video and audio cassettes, information on programs sponsored by the Center, publications, and material from the U.S.-Japan Training Institute.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by the Turner Geriatric Clinic (Donor No. 10450) in November 2010.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The Turner Geriatric Clinic records are open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Turner Geriatric Clinic records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Ivan Duff, a rheumatologist at the University of Michigan, began research into the treatment and care of elderly patients in his practice. Upon learning that psychological, emotional, and social problems affected their health, he initiated programs to emphasize the treatment of these things, and in doing so, pushed for the creation of a clinic dedicated to the prevention and treatment of illness in the elderly while also improving their quality of life. A vote from the University of Michigan Hospital community was taken to determine the necessity of such a clinic. With an endowment from Scott and Amy Prudden Turner that was given to the University Hospital to be used for the benefit of older adults, the Turner Geriatric Clinic was started in 1978. The clinic was designed to offer a wide range of primary health services for elderly patients, including ophthalmology, psychiatry, nursing, physical rehabilitation, dentistry, and education. Duff was appointed the first director and one of his other co-workers, Florence Tillman, was the first nurse of the clinic. Ruth Campbell was employed as a social worker and she worked with Duff to create a committee of elderly people to serve as advisors, friends, and supporters to their peers. The clinic has since hired more people and brought in many volunteers to help with programs. The programs have been educational and supportive, and social programs, including writing circles, have also attracted a large group of people. The clinic distinguishes itself from other clinics like it by offering programs that provide a social support system for non-medical influences in patient's health.

With the growing popularity and success of the Turner Geriatric Clinic, the Turner Senior Resource Center was added in 1998. It serves as an extension of the clinic to house community programs and services. One very successful program from the Center is the Silver Club, a program for seniors with memory loss.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of materials from the Turner Geriatric Clinic that begins when the Center was established in 1979 and ends with records from 2009, with the bulk covering 1990-2008. The collection contains eight series: Personal Files, Photographs, Programs, Publications, Publicity, Topical Files, U.S.-Japan Institute, and Audio-Visual Materials.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Files (0.3 linear feet) series contains information on individuals who were part of the staff of the Geriatric Center, and on elderly individuals who were members of the center. This includes people such as Alma Wooll who was heavily involved in the Center's events. Included within each file are correspondence, general documents, and information on events or programs that the individual was a part of.

The Photographs (0.3 linear feet) series contains a variety of photos from specific events in the Center, as well as a miscellaneous folder. There are photographs from the Living History program that the Center put on, photographs from the Nursing Home Enrichment program, and photographs from the Senior Sing and Swing event.

The Programs (0.9 linear feet) series contains information on events, workshops, and seminars that the Geriatric Center hosted or sponsored. Most files contain generic information, flyers, and correspondence about each program. Programs include the Art Gallery 55+ event where the elderly showcased their personal artwork, the Forgiveness Group where participants attended weekly seminars on how to forgive others and themselves, and the Coming of Age Event when the Center entered into its 21st year of service.

did.unittitle: If You Ask Me, I'll Tell You 2000
Living History -- Sharing Memories of the Chelsea Area 1991

scopecontent.p: The Publications (1.5 linear feet) series contains books and articles produced by the Center itself, or by the people attending the programs at the Center. Included are the publications for Caring for Your Aging Relatives, a seminar for the family members of the elderly, the "Never Say Never" publications written by the Center's writing group, and a collection of poetry by Arvil Brown.

did.unittitle: "Collected Poems and One Essay" by Kathleen Maddox 1995
"Come Be My Love" by Anne-Marie Nilsen
Life History of Jean Lynn Barnard
Memory Stimulation Groups in the Nursing Home Center 1988
Nursing Facility Diversion: Mobilizing Residents, Families and Resources to Facilitate Return to Community Living 2004
Where to Turn: A Guide to Washtenaw County Programs and Services for People Over 60 1992, 1995, 1997-1998, 2001

scopecontent.p: The Publicity (0.7 linear feet) series contains general articles, flyers, and brochures for the Geriatrics Center. A set of folders, titled Programs and Events, are organized chronologically and contain flyers and information on the various programs and events held at the Center throughout each year.

The Topical Files (1.3 linear feet) series contains information on fundraising campaigns, correspondence, partner associations, scrapbooks, awards given by the Center, and the history of the Center, among various other files relating to elder issues.

did.unittitle: Award for Excellence in Social Work 2003, 2005, 2007
Turner Senior Resource Center Space Expansion 2001-2002

scopecontent.p: The U.S.-Japan Institute (2.1 linear feet) series contains the guidebooks and reports for the years of the geriatrics training program held in Japan. The U.S.-Japan Training Institute in Geriatric Care was created in 1992 by the Japanese Ministry of Health and Welfare entering into a partnership with the University of Michigan Geriatrics Center. It was called for due to the rising life expectancy of people in Japan and the need to provide both public and private services to the elderly. The guidebooks in the series are organized chronologically and the English copies are separated from the Japanese copies.

did.unittitle: Improving Quality of Care for People with Dementia and their Caregivers Conference-English 2007
Improving Quality of Care for People with Dementia and their Caregivers Conference-Japanese 2007

scopecontent.p: The Audio-Visual Materials (1.9 linear feet) series contains two subseries. The first, Videocassettes, contains various VHS cassettes produced by the Center and the elderly people involved in it, including videos on training programs and tapes from the Japanese Training Institute. The second subseries, Audiocassettes, contains interview tapes organized alphabetically by the last name of the interviewee or the name of the organization being interviewed. The interviews were conducted as part of a life history project designed to have subjects discuss their lives and experiences.
